title: Improve function `Math.tryAdd`

body: If there is a way to reduce the gas cost while keeping the current behavior (result == 0 in case of overflow), we would obviously be open to that.

> Hello @barakman and thank you for this interresting proposal
> 
> > One important note to point out is that if you choose to accept this suggestion, then it will break any code which happens to rely on both returned value for detecting an overflow, i.e., `if (success == false && result == 0)`.
> 
> I think this is an issue. We care a lot about backward compatibility, and even though we don't know if anyone relies on the result being 0, some users may rely on that.
> 
> This check could make sens if the some project does
> 
> ```solidity
> (uint256 result, bool success) = tryAdd(x, y);
> if (result > 0) {
>     // do stuff
> } else require(success, "overflow");
> ```

As I explained, relying on "False AND Zero" as an indication of overflow, is generally wrong.
Even more wrong, is to rely only on "Zero" as an indication of overflow, and that's **regardless** of my suggestion.
This is because 0 + 0 does not overflow.

In other words, the function may return `(true, 0)` and it may return `(false, 0)`.
The latter indicates an overflow, while the former indicates no overflow.

Your code snippet above is actually a good example of how wrong it is to rely on 0 alone as an indication of overflow.
Anyone using such pattern **at this moment** (i.e., under the current implementation) is subjected to erroneous behavior.

Thank you for your quick response :)

Thanks for these great observations @barakman!

> In other words, the function may return (true, 0) and it may return (false, 0).
> The latter indicates an overflow, while the former indicates no overflow.

Right this is a great point and I also think it may not be a great example of how to not use the library.

I think the issue is that the meaning of the return value is just different semantically. Regardless of whether or not the correct usage is to rely on `0`. I'd expect the most popular use case of `tryAdd` would be to use both the flag *and* the value, otherwise just checking if it'll overflow with `bool overflows = a > b` would do the job.

I like the idea, and the savings look promising. But either we wait until 6.x or release a separate version of `try*` called `unchecked*` (temptatively) so that people can "safely" use unchecked operations and mark the previoius `try*` as deprecated.

Yes, this is exactly what I had in mind as well - in order to avoid breaking the current interface, you implement this in a new function on the current version, which you can name `safeAdd` or something similar, and on the next major-version release, you deprecate the current function - `tryAdd`.
